awd_titl_txt: Nanomanufacturing of Three-Dimensional Nanofiber-Nanoparticle Electrodes for Ultra-low Platinum Fuel Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Today, electric vehicles are the only zero-emission vehicle option. They are either fuel cell and battery-powered. Fuel cells have key advantages over batteries for vehicles with 300-mile driving range, e.g., 6-times higher specific energies (i.e., lower weight-to-power ratio), 6-times lower energy storage (i.e., lower fuel weight), and rapid re-fueling times (i.e., shorter recharge times). Although automakers have engineered solutions to many of the major hurdles to bringing the fuel cell vehicle to the market place, the high cost due to the required precious metal platinum electrodes is a major factor that has limited their mass commercialization. This award investigates the manufacturing of unique nanofiber-nanoparticle fuel cell electrodes, the nanomaterial-electrochemical relationships in these electrodes and their subsequent impact on fuel cell performance. This project establishes a fundamental understanding of designing optimal advanced nanostructured electrodes for fuel cells that significantly lowers the required platinum and therefore lowers their cost. This research provides pathways to mass commercialization of efficient low-cost fuel cells, which can have significant impact on society, where fuel cells will provide alternative energy at a lower environmental cost not only for automobiles, but for stationary power as well. The project's comprehensive experimental and modeling approach to understand the design and functioning of nanostructured electrodes has a significant impact on nanomanufacturing and electrochemical engineering. Outreach and education activities consist of involving K-12 students in fuel cell module technology and recruiting and training underrepresented undergraduate students in the laboratory.

The overall goal of this project is to manufacture electrodes with advanced nanoscale morphologies and understand the impact of morphology on multiple simultaneous reaction/transport phenomena to generate fuel cell energy at higher efficiencies and lower costs. The specific objective is to nanomanufacture new controllable, well-organized three-dimensional (3D) nanofiber-nanoparticle electrodes that exhibit optimal fuel cell performance at ultra-low platinum contents. These new three-dimensional nanostructured electrodes are manufactured via a new process, needleless electrospinning/electrospraying with template-assisted nanofiber collection. A new three-dimensional fuel cell model is also developed to predict fuel cell performance with three-dimensional nanofiber-nanoparticle electrodes to guide in electrode nanomanufacturing. Accurate model parameters are obtained through a comprehensive set of advanced in situ and ex situ experimental techniques that are utilized to carefully characterize and analyze the 3D electrode morphology, electrochemical reaction rates, and transport properties. The new process produces fuel cell electrodes with advanced nanoscale morphologies that overcome previous shortcomings of severe transport and reaction limitations in low platinum loaded conventional fuel cell electrodes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project is to catalyze the success of fuel cells in the marketplace by developing a new method for mass production/manufacturing (high production rate) of new controllable, well-organized three-dimensional (3D) nanofiber-nanoparticle electrodes with optimal fuel cell performance at ultra-low platinum (Pt) contents (low cost). The unique new process developed in this work (needleless electrospinning/electrospraying (E/E) with template-assisted collection) allows for low-cost, high-power density fuel cells to be realized.

 

Intellectual Merit: All of the objectives in this work were systematically achieved. Results include the (1) high production rate of nanofibers via needleless electrospinning [1], high production rate of 3D nanofiber-nanoparticle fuel cell electrodes via needleless electrospinning/electrospraying with templated assisted collection [2,3], and high production rate 3D nanofiber-nanoparticle fuel cell electrodes via alternating needleless electrospinning/electrospraying [4]. The 3D fuel cell electrodes produced in this work all resulted in ultra-low Pt contents (low cost) and higher power density fuel cell performance compared to state-of-the-art fuel cell electrodes. The new manufacturing process developed in this work differs significantly from any other electrode manufacturing techniques, where high production rates and a higher level of control over morphology is possible and results in high fuel cell performance.

 

Broader Impacts: The mass commercialization of efficient low-cost fuel cells will have significant impact on society, where this device will provide alternative energy at a lower environmental cost. The fundamental knowledge gained from this project not only has an impact on fuel cells, but numerous other electrochemical-based processes, such as capacitors, electrolysis (hydrogen production), flow batteries (large-scale energy storage), electrodialysis (desalination of water), reverse electrodialysis (ocean/blue energy), and the chloralkali process (production of sodium hydroxide and chlorine from brine). Our comprehensive experimental and modeling approach in understanding the manufacturing and underlying mechanisms with 3D electrodes will have a significant impact on nanomanufacturing and electrochemical engineering. Overall, this project specifically contributed to the research training of three PhD students and two undergraduate students (one underrepresented student). The research results from this project were disseminated to the broader scientific community through numerous publications in high-impact journals and presentations at national research conferences.

 

[1] Hwang, M.; Karenson, M.O.; Elabd, Y.A. ACS Appl. Polym. Mater. 2019, 1, 2731-2740.

[2] Hwang, M.; Elabd, Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 2019, 44, 6245-6256.

[3] Yang, Y.; Sun, R.; Elabd, Y.A. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 2022, 47, 8993-9003.

[4] Kim, D.; Elabd, Y.A. In preparation for submission to Int. J. Hydrogen Energy.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2022
Modified by: Yossef A Elabd
